The biggest problem with today's mainstream comics is that they no longer provide any entry point for younger readers. After the 1960s and '70s, when comics "grew up" Marvel and DC both aimed at a more "mature" audience, with darker, more violent, more fetishistic and sexualized material, and they have lost the ability to connect with younger readers. By younger, I mean kids who are five or six years old, and who can learn to read with comics (as I did) and grow up to buy them for a few years and either keep being nerd-fans or outgrow them. Nowadays the only entry point is basically for tween-to-teen boys (and a very few girls) but the mainstream comicbook world is pretty barren when it comes to little kids. The few titles they offer for this market tend to be jokey and self-referential (Tiny Titans) or of inconsistent quality (Billy Batson) and only one in a hundred are pure gold (Supergirl: Cosmic Adventures In The 8th Grade; Mary Jane Loves Spidey) and these tend to get canceled quickly.

As a parent who grew up reading comics and wants to share this imaginative medium with my kid, I've found it hard to find appropriate material, especially for a young *girl* to read. Although independent publishers have created some great one-off titles, the industry as a whole seems to have lost its ability to reach out to younger, more innocent readers, and can't help slathering on gratuitously violent "realism" or reflexive, tiresome irony. They have a tin ear for the kind of bold, simple, innocent verve that made the great books of the so-called "Silver Age" of comics so much fun to read. But continuing to print the same kind of stuff over and over, without layering their product to accommodate more than one kind of reader, will doom them in the end: too much of the same thing is, simply, boring. Like many older fans, I've drifted away from comics, but still cherish the medium, and wish it were easier to find books to recommend to other parents and kids. (ReadThatAgain.com)

The problem is that comics are no longer readily accessible to kids. Nowadays kids usually have to go well out of their way to get to a comic-book shop where older men tend to proliferate. It used to be that kids could snag a comic book at the supermarket and beg Mom to buy it. You could also easily get them at drug stores and convenience stores. So, it was much more conducive to impulse buying--or at least kids pressuring parents into impulse buying for them. Once access to them became limited to specialized shops, the death knell of comic books was sounded.

When my son, backed with great enthusiasm by his mother, needed my permission to play football, I refused, based on my knowledge of concussions and brain trauma. This case, as with boxing, indicates that blunt trauma can kill. In boxing, Ernie Schaff is still remembered for dying in the ring.

It is of great importance that no aspirin or non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are given for headaches associated with trauma. They inactivate platelets and allow intracranial bleeding to continue or worsen after the period of injury. Aspirin inactivates platelets permanently and NSAIDs for 4-6 hours. It takes more than 4 days for the effect of one aspirin to wear off. Platelets are the first line of defense for bleeding anywhere in the body.

The loss of this young man is tragic.

Dear Gus from OR -- #202. Oh, would that we could all afford to purchase and maintain only cars, homes and goods that are environmentally friendly. Unfortunately, for anyone who earns less than $250,000 per year, that is extremely difficult if not impossible. More than ever, though, we are recycling, carpooling, shopping more carefully, and as much as possible avoiding products that are harmful to us and to the earth, etc. It's not possible for all of us to ride a bicycle to work or to run errands and shop. And, not all of us can grow our own vegetables and churn our own butter, or afford to purchase food from small farmers and green grocers; we would if we could. If you have some tips that would help the average citizen to conserve even more, regardless of their income -- or in the current economic environment -- the lack of it, that would be great.

Meanwhile, we should not hesitate to speak out against this travesty? Are you suggesting that we throw in the towel, shut up and let the robber barons and radical politicans get in bed with foreign countries with U.S. technology and continue this "thoughtless assault on the earth" without an outcry? Now is not the time to be quiet, and none of us has to be perfect in order to protest this outrage. In addition to commenting on this story, those who don't approve of the Exxon-Russia deal should let their elected representatives, on all levels, know. Freedom of speech and the ability to vote are powerful tools that we should all use.
Exxon is investing up to 500 billion in the Russian economy, almost 1.5x Apple Inc. market cap, in order to explore for potential oil fields yet I can't buy a Cuban cigar?

I disagree with the article. It fails to address a couple of critical issues. I currently work for an EADS supplier in Germany and have followed (more by personal interest than by work need) the development of the Superjet plane.

So, first issue: The soviet era planes are not a good reference. Those planes were designed and built utilizing only Russian suppliers. For the superjet Sukhoi is doing what Boeing and Airbus do, utilize an international network of hi-tech suppliers from more than 100 countries, including names like Honeywell, Raytheon,Thales, etc. For example, the Superjet avionics are the same used by the A380. Additionally, the soviet planes were not intended to meet international standards; in contrast, the superjet was designed from scratch for the international market, with the target to meet International standards and pursue certifications.

Second issue: In the competitive Aviation industry money talks. With one third the cost of competitive planes and 10% lower operating costs, airlines are listening carefully. Has more than 200 orders and at least one USA company (Willis Lease) has ordered six with an option to four more.
Sukhoi is not Embraer or Bombardier, is far a more technological advanced player. Boeing should not make the same denial mistake Ford and GM did with the Japanese competitors.

I live in New Haven, CT, and there, by and large the only real damage was wind inflicted, of course by trees. A lot of people and industrial areas still don't have power.

Perhaps now our leaders will see that we need to stop wasting lives and wealth in foreign wars, and bring the money home to deal with emergency situations like this! Where it is needed!
